sentences: Kim Hyun-ah (born June 6, 1992), better known by the mononym Hyuna, is a South Korean singer-songwriter, rapper and model.
section: N/A

sentences: She debuted as a member of the girl group Wonder Girls in February 2007.
section: N/A

sentences: After leaving the ensemble shortly after, Hyuna subsequently left JYP Entertainment and joined the girl group 4Minute, under Cube Entertainment.
section: N/A

sentences: 4Minute debuted in June 2009 and went on to become one of the most popular girl groups in the country.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2010, Hyuna began a solo career with a style she described as "performance-oriented music".
section: N/A

sentences: Her solo debut single "Change" charted at number-two on South Korea's Gaon Digital Chart.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2011, Hyuna gained wider public recognition with the release of her first extended play Bubble Pop!.
section: N/A

sentences: The title track sold more than three million digital copies and she became the first female K-pop solo artist to reach 100 million views on a single music video on YouTube.
section: N/A

sentences: Later the same year, she formed the duo Trouble Maker with former Beast member Hyunseung, releasing the hit single "Trouble Maker".
section: N/A

sentences: In 2012, she appeared in a successful duet rendition of Psy's worldwide hit "Gangnam Style" and later released her second extended play Melting, which featured the number-one single "Ice Cream".
section: N/A

sentences: Her next two extended plays A Talk and A+ yielded the successful singles "Red" and "Roll Deep", respectively.
section: N/A

sentences: Following 4Minute's disbandment in mid-2016, she released her fifth extended play A'wesome, which was supported by her first concert tour The Queen's Back.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2017, she was involved in the trio Triple H with Pentagon members Hui and E'Dawn before releasing her sixth extended play Following.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2018, Hyuna ended her contract with Cube Entertainment after several internal conflicts, and signed with Psy's P Nation the following year.
section: N/A

sentences: Her first digital single under P Nation "Flower Shower" became her seventh top-ten entry on the US Billboard World Digital Song Sales.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2021, Hyuna released her seventh extended play I'm Not Cool.

sentences: Hyuna was born on June 6, 1992 in Seoul, South Korea.

sentences: However, Hyuna's Chinese teacher told her that it sounded bizarre in Mandarin (pinyin: Xuàn Wǒ, which could be translated as "I weep") and recommended she adopt the characters "泫雅" (pinyin: Xuàn Yǎ) as her name for promotional activities in Taiwan, which she agreed to, commenting that "泫雅" sounded adorable.

sentences: In 2006, she was revealed as a member of the JYP Entertainment managed girl group Wonder Girls as the group's main rapper.

sentences: Hyuna participated in the group's debut mini album The Wonder Begins, released in February 2007.

sentences: She participated in the group's television show MTV Wonder Girls for two seasons, and co-hosted Show!

sentences: Music Core with Wonder Girls' Sohee and Fly to the Sky singer Brian Joo from May 12 – June 30, 2007.

sentences: Hyuna left Wonder Girls in July, when she was removed by her parents due to their concern over her health, particularly chronic gastroenteritis and fainting spells.

sentences: In 2008, she joined Cube Entertainment.

sentences: On August 13, she rapped for Navi's song "Wasteful Tears" and she also appeared in the music video.

sentences: Hyuna also featured in Brave Brothers' song "Bittersweet," released August 18.

sentences: Their first digital single "Tomorrow" was released on October 6, 2009, and the official music video was released on October 12, starring actor Lee Dong-gun.

sentences: As well, Hyuna released an individual version of the music video which released on October 27.

sentences: She also participated in the South Korean variety show Invincible Youth.

sentences: However, Hyuna left the show due to some scheduling conflicts with her group's overseas promotions on June 11, 2010.

sentences: On January 4, 2010, she released the single "Change", which charted highly on various online charts.

sentences: The song reached number fourteen on the Gaon 2010 digital yearly chart with 2,469,354 copies sold.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2010: Solo debut and rising success ===

sentences: Ten days later, on January 14, the "Change" music video was flagged with a 19+ rating by the Ministry of Gender Equality and Family for being inappropriate for minors.

sentences: Cube Entertainment stated that the music video would be re-edited and submitted for approval.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2010: Solo debut and rising success ===

sentences: However, broadcast station SBS, announced the music video would be restricted for a 15+ audience instead, and MBC announced that it would still be viewable for all audiences.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2010: Solo debut and rising success ===

sentences: Hyuna's "Change" promotions ended in March 2010.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2010: Solo debut and rising success ===

sentences: She released a few more singles in 2010, including "Love Parade" featuring T-max's member Park Yun-hwa, "Outlaw in the Wild" featuring Nassun, and produced by E-Tribe.

sentences: It eventually became the first music video by a K-pop artist to surpass 100 million views.

sentences: Hyuna was ranked 17th on Billboard's '21 Under 21′, a staff-compiled list of notable young acts; while "Bubble Pop" was listed as ninth place on Spin magazine's "Best 20 Songs of 2011."
